Package com.rb.nonbiz.collections

Class RBLists

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.collections.RBLists
public class RBLists
extends java.lang.Object
Various static methods pertaining to List objects.

  • Method Details

    • listConcatenation

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.List<K> listConcatenation​(java.util.List<K>... lists)
      Concatenates a bunch of lists into a single one. Sounds simple, but I can't find some library that already does this.

    • listConcatenation

      public static <K> java.util.List<K> listConcatenation​(java.util.Iterator<java.util.List<K>> listIterator)
      Concatenates a bunch of lists into a single one. Sounds simple, but I can't find some library that already does this.

    • listConcatenationWithoutDuplicates

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.List<K> listConcatenationWithoutDuplicates​(java.util.List<K>... lists)
      Concatenates a bunch of lists into a single one, but eliminates duplicates. This assumes that K implements a nontrivial equals/hashCode, which our classes typically do not, so be careful.

    • concatenateFirstAndRest

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.List<K> concatenateFirstAndRest​(K first, K... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

    • concatenateFirstAndRestDoubles

      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

      @SafeVarargs public static <K> java.util.List<K> concatenateFirstSecondThirdAndRest​(K first, K second, K third, K... rest)
      This is for a common case for specialized static constructors (which usually live in test) that want to force you to supply at least one item. But it can be used anywhere.

    • intersection

      public static <K> java.util.List<K> intersection​(java.util.List<K> list1, java.util.List<K> list2)
      Unlike Sets.intersection or RBSets.intersection, this will preserve the order in the 1st list. Contrast this with sets, where the intersection (which itself is returned as a set) can be in any order.

    • deterministicOrderedListComparator

      public static <K extends java.lang.Comparable<K>> java.util.Comparator<java.util.List<K>> deterministicOrderedListComparator()
      deterministic implies 'it's a fixed order, but not guaranteed' ordered means we don't reorder items within the lists. Without loss of generality, if you assume K to be a char, then these will sort like in a dictionary: 'ant' comes before 'bee', and 'ant' comes before 'anti'.

    • listItemsAreUnique

      public static <T> boolean listItemsAreUnique​(java.util.List<T> items)

    • getFirstNonUniqueListItem

      public static <T> java.util.Optional<T> getFirstNonUniqueListItem​(java.util.List<T> list)

    • sortEfficientlyToList

      @SafeVarargs public static <T,​ C extends java.lang.Comparable<C>> java.util.List<T> sortEfficientlyToList​(java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream, java.util.function.Function<T,​C> primaryScoringFunction, java.util.Comparator<T>... cheaperSubsequentComparators)
      This is useful for cases where the items in the iterator can be given some sort of score (of type C) that's cheap to do comparisons on, but expensive to calculate. Example: some double score that gets calculated using a complex calculation. We also allow for secondary, tertiary, etc. comparators. For example, when we sort tax lots by loss per share, if that's the same, we want to have some deterministic sorting on lot open date and quantity. All of this is done to avoid calling 'scoringFunction' O(n * logn) times under the hood in the process of sorting, which would be bad, e.g. with the following code (ignoring secondary etc. sorts for clarity): 
       
     return newArrayList(iterator)
        .sorted(comparing(v -> scoringFunction.apply(v)))
        .collect(Collectors.toList());

    • listConcatenationFromEach

      public static <X,​ Y> java.util.List<Y> listConcatenationFromEach​(java.util.Collection<X> items, java.util.function.Function<X,​java.util.stream.Stream<Y>> transformer)
      For every item in the collection, we will use the supplied function to create another list of items of type Y. Then, we will concatenate everything into a single List<Y>. This can be done with a bunch of inline streams and flatMap operations, but calling this method is easier to read.

    • listConcatenationFromEachPair

      public static <X1,​ X2,​ Y> java.util.List<Y> listConcatenationFromEachPair​(java.util.Collection<X1> listX1, java.util.Collection<X2> listX2, java.util.function.BiFunction<X1,​X2,​java.util.List<Y>> transformer)
      For every combination of items in the first and second collection, we will use the supplied function to create another list of items of type Y. Then, we will concatenate everything into a single List<Y>. This can be done with a bunch of inline streams and flatMap operations, but calling this method is easier to read.

    • newRBListWithExpectedSize

      public static <T> java.util.List<T> newRBListWithExpectedSize​(int size, java.util.Iterator<T> iterator)

    • pasteLists

      public static <T,​ T1,​ T2> java.util.List<T> pasteLists​(java.util.List<T1> list1, java.util.List<T2> list2, java.util.function.BiFunction<T1,​T2,​T> pasteTransformer)
      Create a list that has the same size as the two input lists (which are expected to have the same size), each element of which is the function of the corresponding items (for the same list index) from the two input lists.

    • findIndexOfFirstConsecutivePair

      public static <T> java.util.OptionalInt findIndexOfFirstConsecutivePair​(java.util.List<T> list, java.util.function.BiPredicate<T,​T> consecutivePairPredicate)
      For a list of 2+ items, find the first index i such that items i and i+1 match a predicate.

    • possiblyReduceConsecutiveItems

      public static <T> java.util.List<T> possiblyReduceConsecutiveItems​(java.util.List<T> list, java.util.function.BiPredicate<T,​T> mustReduceItems, java.util.function.BinaryOperator<T> reducer)
      Returns a copy of the initial list where consecutive items may be 'reduced' (as in map/reduce).

      This is different than 'reducing' a list, e.g. adding a bunch of numbers, which results in a single number. Instead, this returns a list (not a scalar), where certain sublists inside it may be reduced into a single value. The tests may explain this better.

    • listsAreSimilar

      public static <T> boolean listsAreSimilar​(java.util.List<T> list1, java.util.List<T> list2, java.util.function.BiPredicate<T,​T> itemsAreSimilar)
      This is similar to List equality, except that, instead of using the default Object.equals(Object) method to compare two items for equality, it uses the supplied BiPredicate.

      We typically avoid implementing equals/hashCode in our codebase, because prod code rarely needs it, and test code uses hamcrest matchers. So this is useful in cases where plain list equality wouldn't work.

    • transformUsingBothIndexAndValue

      public static <T1,​ T2> java.util.List<T2> transformUsingBothIndexAndValue​(java.util.List<T1> list, java.util.function.BiFunction<java.lang.Integer,​T1,​T2> externalIterationTransformer)
      Transforms a list to a different one using 'external iteration', i.e. knowledge of both the value being transformed, but also the numeric index that we're in.

    • copyWithModifiedElement

      public static <T> java.util.List<T> copyWithModifiedElement​(java.util.List<T> originalList, int index, java.util.function.UnaryOperator<T> operator)
      A convenience method to create a copy of the original list with only one if its elements changed.
